description: From Latin iōta, from Ancient Greek ἰῶτα (iôta). Doublet of iota.

entries.meaning: Iota; the smallest letter or stroke of any writing.
examples: Ye shall abide; man’s heart is false and vile.”

entries.meaning: A small amount, bit; the smallest amount.
examples: He didn't care a jot for his work.

entries.meaning: A brief and hurriedly written note.
examples: "I say, it is no uneven jot, to pass from the more faint and obscure examples of Spermatical life to the more considerable effects of general Motion in Minerals, Metalls, and sundry Meteors ..."
Making my Death familiar to my Tongue
Digs not my Grave one Jot before the Date.

verbs.description: jot (third-person singular simple present jots, present participle jotting, simple past and past participle jotted)

examples: Tell me your order, so I can jot it down.
